content.body:
> <@bakkot:matrix.org> maybe it's just that the `arrayBuffer` method predates the more general tendency to prefer `Uint8Array`?

I think this is likely.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @bakkot:matrix.org
maybe it's just that the arrayBuffer method predates the more general tendency to prefer Uint8Array?
I think this is likely.

content.body: Figure there's any appetite for adding a `.bytes()` method to get a Uint8Array? It feels a bit unnecessary given that you can just do `new Uint8Array(await body.arrayBuffer())`, but it would be more consistent in allowing people to never think about ArrayBuffers
content.formatted_body: Figure there's any appetite for adding a .bytes() method to get a Uint8Array? It feels a bit unnecessary given that you can just do new Uint8Array(await body.arrayBuffer()), but it would be more consistent in allowing people to never think about ArrayBuffers

content.body: I think so. Seems uncontroversial, but also the kind of thing that would benefit from someone being willing to submit patches since it's not exactly fitting into any team's quarterly goals.
bakkot: that seems reasonable. We'd have to add it to some other APIs too that copied Fetch. And maybe we should annotate `arrayBuffer()` somehow so it doesn't get copied further.
content.formatted_body: bakkot: that seems reasonable. We'd have to add it to some other APIs too that copied Fetch. And maybe we should annotate arrayBuffer() somehow so it doesn't get copied further.

content.body: a quick glance through https://dontcallmedom.github.io/webidlpedia/names/ArrayBuffer.html suggests it has been copied only to PushMessageData and Blob, which isn't too bad so far
Yeah, that sounds about right.
FileReader also has `readAsArrayBuffer` which is a bit odd
content.formatted_body: FileReader also has readAsArrayBuffer which is a bit odd

content.body: Right, we don't have to care about updating FileReader though. It's kinda like XHR (which also has responseType = "arrayBuffer" come to think of it).
huh, wonder why that doesn't show up on the WebIDLpedia page
anyway yeah
Probably because it's an enum value?
* Right, we don't have to care about updating FileReader though. It's kinda like XHR (which also has responseType = "arraybuffer" come to think of it).

m.new_content.body: Right, we don't have to care about updating FileReader though. It's kinda like XHR (which also has responseType = "arraybuffer" come to think of it).

content.body: I'd expect it to show up in the algorithm, though. maybe the enum value gets threaded through to Fetch?
anyway, if "things which vend bytes should vend Uint8Arrays specifically, not ArrayBuffer" is indeed a general principle to follow, might also be worth documenting in the design principles?
bakkot: XHR has responseType (takes an enum) and response (which returns the type corresponding to the enum)
content.formatted_body: bakkot: XHR has responseType (takes an enum) and response (which returns the type corresponding to the enum)

content.body: hmm, https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/#the-response-attribute does refer to "a new ArrayBuffer object", and ArrayBuffer links; not sure why WebIDLpedia wouldn't pick up on it.
possibly because of https://github.com/whatwg/xhr/issues/376 I guess
anyway, not super important
bakkot: I think you are confusing the IDL index with https://dontcallmedom.github.io/webdex/a.html#ArrayBuffer%40%40%40%40interface
content.formatted_body: bakkot: I think you are confusing the IDL index with https://dontcallmedom.github.io/webdex/a.html#ArrayBuffer%40%40%40%40interface

content.body: bakkot: response uses any in its IDL which is why it's not on WebIDLpedia
content.formatted_body: bakkot: response uses any in its IDL which is why it's not on WebIDLpedia

content.body: Andreas Kling: https://twitter.com/eatonphil/status/1747732476468826446 hah! The independent SQL implementation WebSQL wanted, but never got.
content.formatted_body: Andreas Kling: https://twitter.com/eatonphil/status/1747732476468826446 hah! The independent SQL implementation WebSQL wanted, but never got.
